awd_titl_txt: EARS: Cloud-based Oblivious Spectrum Mapping and Allocation
awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamic spectrum access (DSA) techniques offer the potential to use the radio spectrum more efficiently by allowing radios to sense which parts of the radio spectrum are not currently being used by the licensed users or other opportunistic users. However, detecting the presence of transmissions in a particular band is difficult because of randomness in the radio propagation environment and because radio signals can be received at very low power levels. Sensing the radio spectrum can be made more accurate by collecting and processing the sensing information from multiple radios. However, in combining this information, the locations and characteristics of the sensing radios may be revealed to the other radios or to various companies involved in collecting and combining the information. 

This research project will develop novel techniques to protect the privacy of users involved in sensing the radio spectrum as part of a DSA system. The techniques are built on top of secure computing primitives, such as garbled circuits, which uses cryptographic techniques to allow users to compute a result without any of the parties being able to know the other parties inputs to the computation. Although complete privacy is not possible in a spectrum sensing system, this project aims to develop systems that achieve k-anonymity, in which a user's location and capabilities may only be reduced to one of k possibilities. A significant challenge in developing such techniques is that many secure computing primitives require high computational complexity, and thus cannot be implemented on many DSA devices, such as future generations of cellular phones. Thus, the project will develop privacy-preserving spectrum sensing techniques that have sufficiently low complexity to be implemented on such devices. One of the approaches to achieving this is to partition the computation between the devices and a cloud-computing server.  These techniques will be implemented on a software-defined radio testbed that interfaces with a commercial cloud computing resource to allow testing using real radio signals and real computing platforms.

por.por_cntn:
Exisitng wireless communication systems mostly rely on govermental allocation of the radio spectrum to determine which radios can use which radio channels in a given area. This approach is often wasteful, as the allocated users do not always use these resources.

More modern approaches use a dynamic approach in which unutilzed channels can  be detected and then utilized by other radios, but these approaches must protect legacy users by sensing when and where they are using the radio channels. More generally, the dynamic users want to create a map of the radio channel usage across space (i.e., in different geographic ares). However, the radios must collaborate by exchanging information that they sense about the usage of the radio channels in order to create such a map, and when they do, they generally leak information about their own locations. Such information may reveal important details about the life of the radio's user, and thus needs to be protected.

In this project, we developed techniques for radios to exchange information in such a way that an adversary who has access to the information stream (even a participant in the process) can get information about the set of locations but cannot associate them with particular devices or users, thus providing a form of anonymity for the radios that are collaborating to create the map. We provide algorithms for combining noisy measurements at different radios to determine where a user of the radio spectrum is most likely located. These allgorithms are designed to allow the information to be processed by the radios/mobile devices themselves (in a distributed way) or at a centralized processor (in the "cloud"). Encryption techniques are used to help hide radios' identities and measurements from adversaries. The algorithms are run inside a protected are of the processors in the mobile radios or the cloud server(s). These protected areas are called "secure enclaves", and they allow the information to be combined without the radio that is doing the combining having general access to the measurements and radio identities.

We implemented the privacy-preserving localization algorithms on two different secure enclaves. The Intel SGX enclaves are typically found more on desktop or server devices and would be appropriate for cloud computing solutions. The AMD TrustZone enclaves are avaialble on mobile devices, but tend to be less efficient. We show that either implementation can be practically used provided the numbers of measurements and radios does not grow too large. These new approaches may be leveraged in future wireless communication systems to allow users to colalborate to build maps of the use of radio channels over space, while providing a form of anonymity for the collaborators.

In addition to the research, we also developed a lab on communications and spectrum sharing that is targeted toward middle school students. This lab consists of activities in which the participants use audio signals instead of radio frequency signals, so they can better experience what goes in to coordinating use of the radio spectrum among multiple users. All of the lab materials has been put on the web for other groups to use in teaching about these topics.
